intro: Pimpinella isaurica subsp. sumbuliana, commonly known as the Isaurian cow-wheat, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbel-like flower clusters. It is a perennial herb with slender, branched stems and finely divided, fern-like leaves. The flowers are small, white to pale yellow, and arranged in compound umbels, typical of the carrot family. It thrives in rocky, calcareous soils and is often found in mountainous regions of the Mediterranean. This subspecies is notable for its ornamental value and ecological importance in supporting pollinators.
